prop.head.headtext: Legal Bases Used by the Courts for the Protection of Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: Criticism—Not All Breaches of Confidential Business Information Are Covered by Contracts

para.paratext: The problems encountered as a result of the appropriation of confidential information may not always be solved by invoking the law of contract. This is particularly so if the plaintiff's action is brought, not against the other contracting party, but against a third party who acquired the secret from the other contracting party. This may also be true where two parties enter into abortive negotiations, during the course of which confidential information is communicated.[1]

Because there are many situations in which confidential business information is appropriated where there is no express or implied contract in place, contract law cannot be the basis of a right to confidential business information per se. It is submitted that the failure to take into account the cases where liability has been imposed in the absence of any contractual relationship between the parties is the most serious flaw in the contract theory.
G. Jones, “Restitution of Benefits Obtained in Breach of Another's Confidence” (1970), 86 L.Q.R. 463.
